data.title: Beautiful Architecture, lots of resources!
data.text: Built by H.H. Richardson who also designed the beautiful Trinity Church in Copley Square, Thomas Crane Library is beautiful & historic.  There's an atrium in the lobby with a snack bar, excellent kids room on the ground level, with collections for adults and teens and computers free to use with an account on the upstairs floors (elevator also).  Excellent source for free or discounted museum passes for those with a library card.  With an entrance from Spear Street behind the library, the Crane Library Bookstore sells used books and is open on Thursday from 6-8 and Saturday from 10-4.

data.title: Knowledge center
data.text: Good place for kids and for adults also. First floor you can find kids section and on other end small cafe. Second floor lots of books audio,video for adults. Third floor newspapers. Printing sections. You can borrow up $100 of book etc.

data.title: Great Library
data.text: very organized and easy to use,staff very friendly.  Very big computer room with multiple copy machines.  Staff very helpful.  Couldn't find anything to complain about.

data.title: One of the First
data.text: IT's a beautiful library set in a very historic city...If you are interested in old buildings then it is worth the time...Multi level and full of many interesting books ,displays , and other items of interest..

data.title: love this library
data.text: always plenty of activities, the building is attractive, can find a quiet spot if needed, computers and printers available

data.title: Beautiful and quiet
data.text: If you find the older part of the building, you'll find the nicest part of the library.  Good selection of materials, too.

data.title: Fantastic facility
data.text:
From the outside this is a fantastic building. It is absolutely gorgeous. With its multi colored stone it resembles a church more than a plain Library. The design is great and the setting on verdant large green invites many people to just lay a blanket down and read. The interiors are classic: hardwood floors, stain glass windows, intricate woodwork, everything you expect from an architectural gem.
     The staff is terrific. Knowledgeable, helpful and enthusiastic in their mission. Great resources are available here. I feel this is very comparable to the Boston Public Library

data.title: Architectural gem
data.text: Even if you don't read this is a spot you should visit if only to see the beautiful inside and outside. The library does offer tours, contact them for times. The historic old library building is in the center of Quincy, the City of Presidents. A later addition was designed to compliment and pay homage to the original building. Worth a stop.

data.title: Terrific Library
data.text: An excellent library with all the resources you'll need. They also have a very nice café with free Wi-Fi.

data.title: Fantastic building just to see
data.text: This is a great place, there are two parts, the old part is absolutely beautiful and worth a look see. It is a great community place with tons of programs for old and young. Biggest problem can be parking, there is a parking lot but you may have to wait, depends on the time of day and event happening.

data.title: A wonderful library.
data.text: I moved to Quincy from England in 1996 & since then the library has more than tripled in size. It has everything from books,DVD's,computers & also an area which has a vast selection of magazines. There is parking & you can usually find a spot although sometimes it does fill up, meaning a short wait.

data.title: TC is Tops
data.text:
I recently attended a string concert in the beautifully appointed Thomas Crane Library. I'll admit, although I lived in Quincy & graduated from Quincy High School, I had not been in this absolutely beautiful library since, probably, my graduation many years ago.  As I sat & listen to the music, my eyes wandered to the polished woods of the floors, the balcony above, the sunlight pouring through the floor to ceiling windows and wondered to myself, "what took you so long to return here"?  
The architecture of the building is nothing short of magnificent. The original building was designed by H.H. Richardson in 1882 with 3 additional stages added over the years ending with the last addition in 2001 by a brilliant team of Boston based architects.   
When the concert finished, I took a few minutes to wander around some of the familiar grounds I remembered from QHS days. I located the huge stained glass window that was designed by John Lafarge ~~ a memory from a French IV class tour back in the day.
The pristinely landscaped grounds were designed by Frederick Law Olmstead of the Emerald Necklace & Central Park fame.
All-in-all, I still have to reflect and ask myself why? Why when I live only minutes away do I not take advantage of this absolutely extraordinary and lovely spot right in my neighborhood?  
The TC rocks and I have made it a point to return there several more times since the concert 2 months ago.  You should go there too!

data.title: Beautiful building & great children's programs
data.text: This is a beautiful spot in the heart of Quincy Center.  The library is well-stocked with both adult and children's books. As a neighbor, we also love the free programs offered for children

data.title: Welcome to the Castle
data.text: From the outside it's a cross between a church and a castle.  Inside all the items you'd want in a spacious, modern library, including a children's room, an open café area where teens can hang out, computer access, and interesting programs and events.  Don't overlook the open mike on last Mondays or the almost sacred -feeling older wing which will feel like time-travel with its old-fashioned hush and high stained glass windows (great spot for laptop work).  And now, a shout-out to the librarians, always pleasant and helpful!

data.title: Best Library on the South Shore
data.text: First, this is a beautiful place-- the old building, which housed the original library, is still in use and it's like a museum, with hard-wood floors, stained glass windows, a fireplace, and rare historical artifacts;  it also houses a huge collection of old magazines from all over the US. The new building is airy and spacious, with plenty of computers, an amazing children's room (which has activities and story-telling), and of course, several floors of books, reference materials, etc.  If you ever need to do microfilm research (since not everything is online), you've come to the right place:  the Thomas Crane Library has complete runs of the Quincy Patriot and Quincy Patriot-Ledger going back to the 1800s. There's also a section for Chinese-language materials (Quincy has a sizable immigrant population). In short, this is a great place to visit with kids, and a fine place to do research.

data.title: More than Books - Sunday Concerts too
data.text: Our visit included help for a friendly and welcoming staff and a wonderful violin recital which was free. The HH Robinson designed building is inviting and impressive. We especially liked the fine old woodwork.

data.title: Quincy stationから徒歩圏内の歴史を感じる図書館
data.text: 駅から歩いて5分ほどの所にあるパブリックの図書館です。３階建てです。たいてい座る事が出来ます。正面入り口を入ってひたすら左側に進んで行くと、プライベート空間のような所があります。古い本などが置かれています。
